fields.description: When creating a new bug, if you don't assign a component and try to save the bug, the system keeps you on the create bug page and tells you that you need to select a component, but the "Assign To" field gets changed from "Automatic" to the Project Lead for some reason.
fields.summary: Assign To field entry changes when error occurs on submit of new bug

fields.description:
Hi
We use JIRA for out internal tracking purpose.
SUddenly for the past 2 days we lost the association between the issues and projects.
If we type the issue ID we are getting the output but if we select the project nothing is displayed of for some projects few of the issues were missing
fields.summary: Project Issue Dis association

fields.description:
Currently when an issue is voted on the history of who voted on what issue is not viewable via the UI. It would be nice if it were for two reasons:
1) it would allow a manual process of getting approval for sizing defects/new features/etc. by giving managers the ability to simply 'vote' for a feature - when enough votes were collected by approved people the 'new feature' issue could be transitioned to the development group to work on.
2) It is concievable that a list of 'approvers' could be created for the issue and when each 'approver' voted on the issue the issue could be automatically transitioned into a new state or some other action could be taken.

These thoughts are all when looking to implement JIRA in a controlled (i.e. internal) environment. There are several ways to meet this need via existing (though manual) efforts. Several of my users siezed on the idea of 'voting' an issue into production and liked it.

-wc
fields.summary: enhance issue voting functionality

fields.description:
When you resolve an issue as a duplicate, we would like the chance to create link duplicate link right then, rather than doing it in a additional two-step process. 

It seems from reading other comments that other people leave duplicate bugs open until they are resolved, but when we find a duplicate, we immediately resolve it as such, even though the original bug has not yet been fixed. This keeps the lists from being cluttered.
fields.summary: When resolving as "duplicate," offer the option to create link on same page

fields.description:
If you have a project with an security scheme that has some default security level, then the CreateIssueHandler does not set the ticket to the default security level. 

It does not set the security level at all.

This is a severe security issue and should be fixed asap.

In our setup this makes all issues created via email visible to all other customers. We have one support project shared by multiple customers. Each customer has their own security level, to show them only their own tickets. The default security level is now set to show the ticket only to the reporter and jira-developers.
fields.summary: CreateIssueHandler does not set default security level to created issues!

fields.description: Currently the Mantis importer sets the "Updated" date to be the time the import was performed.  It is more useful if the last_updated date in the Mantis database were used.
fields.summary: Mantis importer: preserve Last Updated / Modified date

fields.description:
This property entry does not look correct:

$ grep -r opertaions .
./com/atlassian/jira/web/action/JiraWebActionSupport.properties:issue.opertaions.reopen = Reopen
fields.summary: Typo in properties?

fields.description: Mantis issue bodies are all HTML-escaped, eg < for <.  JIRA's Mantis importer is meant to unescape them before insertion into JIRA's database.  However the replaceAll() method only replaces the first character.
fields.summary: Mantis importer: only the first HTML entity replaced

fields.description:
From Craig O'Shannessy:

'When the wiki/blog/whatever pings the ticket URL, you could give back a
the standard "Not Logged In" page, but with the trackback URL hidden in
it just like it would have been if they had got to the real ticket page.
The wiki would then see the hidden trackback URL (not caring that it got
a login page rather than the ticket), and register the trackback.
Jira would probably need an option for "Allow anonymous trackbacks".'

There may be security implications for this - we should investigate.
fields.summary: Allow trackbacks for secure URLs (anonymous trackbacks)

fields.description:
I use JIRA at codehaus.org (as a user, not a committer), and find it frustrating that I can't locate the patches I submit to various projects to see if they've been incorporated.

You can currently search by "Reported by" or "Assignee", but I'd like to see a "Comment by" search option.  This would allow me to quickly see all issues that I've been involved with, and follow-up on them.
fields.summary: Search comment author

fields.description:
Entering a double-quote character, then semicolon, then the string "jsessionid", then an equals sign into any textarea or text box truncates the input at that point.

Discovered while editing an issue, modifying summary, description, and comments.
fields.summary: entering [quote][semicolon]jsessionid[equals] truncates text input

fields.description: When configuring a notification scheme, there is no ability to set set component leads to events. This would be helpful to us as we have projects with many components, and various component leads.  Our notification schemes are "turned down" so as not to become a source of spam emails when hundreds of issues are added/edited each day.
fields.summary: Component Lead should be selectable in the notification scheme

fields.description: It'd be real nice to be able to add comments to comments, so that you could follow a discussion thread on a issue *much* easier.
fields.summary: Allow threaded comments

fields.description: Charles already fixed this for confluence, but under certain versions of IE stylesheets aren't used, making the render really poor. Simple fix: put a .css at the end of it.
fields.summary: Stylesheet is broken (sometimes) on IE with Orion

fields.description:
I tried to change the assignment of several issues to "unassigned" and chose this field from the list of avalable assignments in the bulk editing tool. 
Actually, in the window to confirm the changes the new value was listed as "default assigne" which indeed the issues were assigned to instead of getting "unassigned".
I had to "unassign" all issues manually which worked fine - but took a lot of mouse clicks.
fields.summary: bulk editing: assignment

fields.description:
When the description of a bug is too long, the bug cannot be submitted, as it shows a java.lang.reflect.UndeclaredThrowableException.

This problem is critical, because our customers are complaining they cannot enter detailed description of the bugs.
fields.summary: java.lang.reflect.UndeclaredThrowableException

fields.description: Similar to versions, allow the assigning of issues to a 'Work Packet' or Module, so that issues can be tied to deliverables at a business level.  Versions are great for a technical level, and they keep track of what physically is in each build. By having a gouping of issues by 'Work Packet' a business user can tell when their feature is finished
fields.summary: Create Workpackets or Modules

fields.description: We should allow people to be able to provide their own containers to override the default PicoContainer in JIRA.
fields.summary: Allow pluggable component extensions, so you can plug in your own interfaces

fields.description:
Enable clone issue to also clone subtasks.

If subtasks exist for an issue - the subtasks should be also cloned, linked to the newly cloned parent issue.
fields.summary: Enable clone issue to also clone subtasks.

fields.description:
Enable ability to define field layout schemes per issue type per project.

This is an enterprise feature.

Note: Limits changing issue type of an issue to an issue type that is associated with the field layout scheme used by the original issue type of the issue.
fields.summary: Define field layout schemes per issue type per project

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-3740].
  {panel}

It would be nice if JIRA was able to send out mails when new users sign up. 

This is mostly useful for projects with many members where you need to assign groups to developers after they've signed up. 

If the email could include links to the edit user / edit user groups pages it would be even more useful :)

UPDATE: This feature request should also cover when new users are created by anyone in the application. It would be helpful as if a site has multiple site-admins, it would alert the others when a user is created, as well as if users are created via an external system import.
fields.summary: Notification event to signal new user sign-up / account creation

fields.description:
After doing an XML restore, the statistics stop getting updated.

The workaround is to restart JIRA straight after the restore.
fields.summary: After import JIRA needs to be restarted for statistics to be updated.

fields.description:
Suggestion: take some of the more common field changes and convert them into human-readable text. So for example, this very common "resolve and assign back to reporter"...

   assignee Joe Shmo [ jshmo ]  Jane Jooky [ jjooky ]  
   resolution  Fixed [ 1 ]  
   status Open [ 1 ]  Resolved [ 5 ]  

would look like this instead:

   Joe Shmo [ jshmo] resolved this issue as 'fixed' and assigned it back to Jane Jooky [ jjooky ].

I noticed that the update emails already do this to an extent - while re-prioritizing a bug will get a general "Updated" email with the changed fields listed, resolving will get a specific "Resolved" email that says "The following issue has been resolved as FIXED."
fields.summary: Make human-readable field change notes in log

fields.description:
If a person has permission to edit an issue, but not permission to assign issues in a particular project, if they then edit the issue, they can still see and change the assign field in the edit issue form.

As a workaround, I went into the edit_fields.jsp and changed 

<webwork:if test="id == 'assignee'">
    <jsp:include page="/includes/panels/issue/assignee.jsp" />
</webwork:if>

to 

<webwork:if test="id == 'assignee'">
    <webwork:if test="/hasProjectPermission('assign', project) == true">
        <jsp:include page="/includes/panels/issue/assignee.jsp" />
    </webwork:if>
    <webwork:else>
        <ui:component name="'assignee'" template="hidden.jsp" />
    </webwork:else>
</webwork:if>

Is this workaround OK, or is it incomplete or will it end up breaking something else?
fields.summary: Editing an issue, if you don't have assign rights, you can still change the assign field

2. Enter "Due Date" via Calendar Tool, e.g. 2004-05-28

Results:
- Field Contains "2004Mai28-%b-%Y Due Date"
- Field should contain: "28-05-2004"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-3724].
  {panel}

Problem Statement:
"Basically I want to sort bugs with a filter first on date updated descending and then priority descending. Unfortunately date updated is a time (not a date) and therefore the second sort order has no effect."

Analysis:
To be able to see a list of issues which were worked on for a particular date in order of priority, not priority ordered by the time each issue was updated on a particular date.  Put another way:

Suggested Solution and Feature Request:
Allowing the date field to be split in two would allow a sort on either date alone, time alone and date time together.  This would make the filtering more powerful and solve the problem presented above.
fields.summary: Allow issues to be sorted by date as distinct from "date and time"

fields.description:
This has come from the mail list and as far a i can tell this is how to re create it.

- Create an Issue
- Create a Component
- Edit Issue and give it the new Component

The stats are not updated correctly as the Issue still shows as being in Non Component.

I think the problem is the Statistics Tree does not contain an entry for the new Component so when the Issue is changed it can not be updated in the Tree.
fields.summary: Statistics are not updated when a new Component/Version has been added

fields.description: When a user first logs in, if no project is selected and they click 'Browse Projects' all the categories get listed even if the user has no rights to a project in that category. The Category appears empty, but the Category name is there. Is there a way to have only categories with projects the person has rights to appear in this list? The issue is when an external customer is accessing the system. We were thinking of setting up a category for each customer we service. The issue is we don't want one customer to know who all of our customers are (we have some contracts were we're not allowed to publicize that we do work for them, so we can't have their name listed as described above).
fields.summary: 'Browse Projects' and Categories

fields.description: This is probably because we don't set the content type correctly.

fields.description:
When a subscribed filter gets deleted, there will be NullPointerExceptions when trying to send the results of the (non-existant) search request.

Need to create a consistency check to remove these subscriptions.

For the time being the SQL to find these subscriptions is:
SELECT * FROM filtersubscription where filter_i_d is not in (select id from searchrequest);

(Note, the above SQL will not work on MySQL due to a sub-select).
fields.summary: Create a integrity check that cleans up non-existant subscribed filters.

fields.description: The format of text email notifications is really bad. Since text notifications are the default, some more work should go into making the important amount of information in those messages less cluttered, more organized, and more readable.
fields.summary: Format of text email notifications is terrible

fields.description: I edited the templates under /WEB-INF/classes/templates/email, restarted Tomcat, and created/modified/commented issues. The changes to the templates had no effect.
fields.summary: Changes to email templates have no effect

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-3717].
  {panel}

Previous issues such as JRA-1630 have suggested allowing projects to be nested.  This has been addressed in the "project category" feature.

However, we have a need for projects to have "grouped releases", where we define a single release for a group of projects, and release them all at once.  

As it stands, we either have to define these projects as components of an umbrella project, or define our releases for each project separately.

Defining them as components doesn't cut it, since we need to define permissioning for each one (which JIRA can't do), and defining them all as top-level projects entails too much duplication of data and risk of error.

So while nested projects would be preferred, we could also get by with allowing permissioning at the component level.
fields.summary: Nested projects for grouped releases

fields.description:
Throughout the application appears a German-style concatenation of words in the string "Timetracking" although English words could have been used even more effectively, such as "Time-tracking" or "Time Tracking."  

In the navigation menu on page /admin/ViewIssueFields.jspa and probably elsewhere is a link to "Time Tracking," which is probably the same thing.  I see correct usage in the Documentation, "Configure Time Tracking."  Using multiple names or spellings for a single, technical thing is a common usability flaw.  

"Timetracking" seen, for example, on page /admin/EditFieldLayout

Please consider replacing all occurrences of "Timetracking" with "Time Tracking" for noun and "time-tracking" for adjective.
fields.summary: Is it "Time Tracking" or the German-style concatenation, "Timetracking"

fields.description:
Create Issue page:  see "Original Estimation" field 

Edit Issue page:    see "Original Estimation" field

Issue Details page: see "Original Time Estimated" field 

Humor:  it's sort of like asking for SUMMARY on one page, then reporting it back on another, labeled not SUMMARY, but HARVEY instead, isn't it?  

One-time use of new terms in place of ones that are already established is a common usability flaw.  

Because "Original Estimation" is kind of a vague term that does not suggest the involvement of time, I suggest that one label be used to represent this field everywhere:  "Estimated Time"

This field appears not to be offered among search parameters in the FIND ISSUE feature.  If it were there, I hope it wouldn't be called something different yet again.
fields.summary: Time Estimate:  same data called by multiple names -- confusing

fields.description:
On the Browser Project page, users will often want to see a list of Open or Unresolved issues.  Under "Component/s" and "Versions" it even says, "with open issues" listed (should say "number of open issues").  This establishes "Open" as an issue status.  

However, Users that want a list of Open or Unresolved bugs must accept that there is no "Open" or "Unresolved" preset filter for them to click on.  They must accept the introduction of a new term, "Outstanding," for no apparent reason.  

One-time use of entirely new terms in place of ones that are already defined is a common usability flaw.  Confusion results.  

A single name for each status would be best for users and for documentation.  I'm not yet aware if "Outstanding" is used elsewhere in JIRA.
fields.summary: Browse Project:  what does Outstanding mean?

fields.description:
Page:  /admin/jira/EditLookAndFeel!default.jspa

NOTE the string: 

"The URL for the logo. If prefixed with 'http(s)://' the logo will be fetched absolute, else it is linked relative the the web application root"   

Probably, "the the" ought to be "to the"
fields.summary: Edit Look and Feel:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /secure/BrowseProject.jspa

The list of Preset Filters contains "ALL" -- since there are no other entries in the list consisting of all capital letters, English rules and the capitals demand that this be taken as an acronym, but it apparently is not.  Capital letters always have meaning, so their use must be consistent.  

Since the result of clicking this link is a list of all records in the project, the link should actually read "All" so that confusion among users is made impossible.
fields.summary: Browse Project:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /project/ViewProject.jspa

       1.  Associate a notification scheme and a project
       2.  Edit the scheme (change its name)
       3.  View the project's settings in ADMINISTRATION -> Projects
           NOTE that the Notification Scheme displays the old, no-

fields.description:
Page:  /admin/jira/GlobalPermissions.jspa

"popup screen" should be "pop-up window" -- (a screen cannot be made to pop up, but a window can).  Most folks are Windows users and the term that Microsoft uses is "pop-up window" (see proof in the Windows Help file).
fields.summary: Global Permissions page:  typographical error, "popup screen"

fields.description:
Hard to tell if this is a duplicate issue -- there are others that are certainly similar.  

ADMINISTRATION -> Project -> click Details link for any project

You should see page:  /project/EditProject!default.jspa

The "Default Assignee" drop-down list box contains only two entries, "Unassigned" and "Project Lead" (should be "Project Leader").  

There's a usability glitch here, in my view, that will frustrate newbies.  It appears that projects are allowed to have only of these two Default Assignees.  However, the expectation will certainly be that any user outght be able to accept the mantle of Default Assignee.  So, it looks like a bug, even though it might be working as designed.  

Even better to copy the Bugzilla model and allow a Default Assignee for every Component.
fields.summary: ADMIN -> Edit Project:  only two Default Assignees possible?

fields.description:
Page:  /index.html?clicked=jirahelp

"Don't forget to setup an external database"
"setup" is a noun.  Should be using the verb "set up."

See the Future Perfect (UK) grammar site for an explanation of the proper use of "setup" vs. "set up."  This applies also to "login" vs. "log in" and many other common mix-ups.  

http://www.future-perfect.co.uk/word14.htm
fields.summary: JIRA Help:  grammatical/typographical error -- noun used as verb

fields.description:
Usability problem.  

ADMINISTRATION -> Users & Groups -> User Browser ->
Click on any user name -> Set Password -> enter the same string in the Password and Confirm fields -> click Submit

NOTE that JIRA offers no confirmation message, leaving the user to 
guess if the process worked.  This is non-friendly.
fields.summary: Change Password process gives no confirmation message

fields.description:
Page:  /ForgotPassword!default.jspa

This page is just one example of an error that occurs throughout JIRA.  The problem is that JIRA first asks for input in a field labeled "Username."  Then, throughout the application, it is referred to as "username."  

Proper names of data fields should be capitalized and match their first appearance.  In this case, proper spelling would be "Username."

Secondly, it is confusing to users when various names and spellings are used to refer to a single thing.  On top of this, usability would be served by using familiar English words like "User Name" instead 
of inventing new ones like "username."  Thoughtless introduction of confusion like this hurts usability and adds to the struggle of using JIRA.
fields.summary: Forgot Password page:  typographical error

fields.description:
ADMINISTRATION -> Global Settings -> Global Permissions

Page:  /admin/jira/GlobalPermissions.jspa  reads

"All users need this permission to login to JIRA"

Unfortunately, this is wrong because "login" is a noun.  The verb "log in" is required here.  

If you log in, you have established a login.  
Set up JIRA and you have accomplished its setup.  

Typos add to confusion and damage trust in quality assurance.
fields.summary: Global Permissions page:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /TimeTrackingAdmin!default.jspa

Button text "DeActivate" should be "Deactivate"

Capital letters have definite meanings in English.  This use of the capital A makes no sense.
fields.summary: Time-Tracking Admin page:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /NewApplicationProperties.jspa

"Indexing Language   english" 

should read

"Indexing Language   English"
fields.summary: New Application Properties page:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /admin/jira/GlobalPermissions.jspa
reads: 

"If you wish to set permissions on a project by project basis"
Doesn't make sense grammaically unless you hyphenate 
"project-by-project."

Without the hyphen, English syntax demands that the first occurrence of "project" is the object.  The remaining words then have no place in the syntax and simply make no sense.  

Typos hurt usability and convey an impression of poor or absent software quality assurance.
fields.summary: Global Permission page:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /admin/SenTestMail.jspa

In the "Message Type" drop-down list, "Html" must be changed to 
"HTML" (this is an initialism and has no meaning if not all 
letters are capitalized).   

An initialism is a series of capital letters, each of which is usually the initial of a word.  If an initialism is pronouncable as a word, it is called an acronym.  

Typographical errors convey the unwanted impression of carelessness.
fields.summary: Send Test Mail page:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /admin/SenTestMail.jspa
reads
"Test Message From Jira" 
but should read 
"Test Message From JIRA"

I haven't seen another occurrence of "JIRA" without all letters capitalized.  Should be consistent for usability's sake.
fields.summary: Send Test Mail page:  typographical error

fields.description:
To log bugs against JIRA, need to sign up for an Atlassian ID/password.  Upon successful completion of the signup, see page:  http://jira.atlassian.com/secure/Signup.jspa, which reads:  

"If you forget you password"
but should read
"If you forget your password"
and "Click here to login"
but should read
"Click here to log in"

("login" is a noun, "log in" is a verb
 "signup" is a noun, "sign up" is a verb
 "setup" is a noun, "set up" is a verb)

Typos damage credibility by conveying the impression that quality assurance is not important.
fields.summary: Signing up for JIRA bug DB:  typographical errors

fields.description:
Page:  /user/UserBrowser.jspa

The title says "UserBrowser," which is followed immediately by 
"The User Browser allows you to..."  Is the correct spelling "UserBrowser" or "User Browser?"  

A "QUICK SEARCH" reveals many more hits for "User Browser," so the page's headline/title is wrong.  

Change it from "UserBrowser" to "User Browser" to maintain consistency, which is important to usability.
fields.summary: /user/UserBrowser.jspa:  typographical error

fields.description:
Page:  /secure/BrowseProject.jspa

"Time Tracking Report" should be "Time-Tracking Report" because 
"time-tracking" is the whole adjective.  Without the hyphen, 
English syntax demands that "tracking" must be taken as a verb, in which case this phrase makes no sense.  

Typos hurt business by conveying the impression that software quality assurance is not important.
fields.summary: /secure/BrowseProject.jspa:  typographical error

fields.description:
The appearance of the phrase "Project Lead" throughout JIRA is dumbfounding because of the carelessness it suggests.  It really is an eyesore and instills a sense of worry about the viability of the JIRA product.  This expression is as absurd as "community lead," "political lead," or "religious lead."  

A lead is not a leader.  

"Lead," as a noun, is a competitive advantage in sports or games, a heavy metal, a conductive wire, etc.  A "lead" is simply not a "leader."  "Project Lead" makes no sense.  

Typos and grammatical gaffes convey an image of non-professionalism and of poor or absent software quality assurance.  Typos damage your business.  The appearance of "Project Lead" suggests that no one in the company understands that a lead is not a leader, or that no one in the company cares enough about quality assurance to have gotten this fixed on Day 1.  Of course, this can't be true, but, sadly, this is the impression conveyed.
fields.summary: Typographical error appears throughout app, "Project Lead"

fields.description:
Text reads, 
"You must login or signup for an account ."
should read
"You must log in or sign up for an account."

["login" and "signup" are nouns.  The verb forms are "log in" and "sign up."  Other examples of this simple rule in English are:  

VERB             NOUN
----             ----
"hook up"        "hookup"
"drive through"  "drive-through"
"set up"         "setup"

Also, there's a mysterious space before the period.  Significance unknown.

Typos convey an image of poor or absent software quality assurance and are bad for usability.
fields.summary: /browse/TEMP-8 -- typographical errors

It should only add the JIRA Administrator as a 'To'-recipient and add all other users to the 'Bcc' recipient list.

fields.description:
Enable searching issues based on time tracking fields through addition of a work ratio field/column.

The ratio of actual work vs estimated work is calculated for each issue and displayed in the issue navigator through a new "Work Ratio" column. This ratio is also added to the Lucene indexes in order to enable a range query on this value.

Hence, it will be possible to search for issues based on the ratio of actual work done against the original estimate of work required.

fields.description:
Here is a user-contributed patch:

<%@ page import="java.util.List, java.util.Iterator,
com.atlassian.jira.ManagerFactory, org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericValue"
%>
<%@ taglib uri="webwork" prefix="webwork" %>
                                                                                                                                                             
<item>
<%@ include file="/includes/issue/issuedetails-rss.jsp" %>
                                                                                                                                                             
        <customfields>
        <webwork:iterator value="/validCustomFields()" >
            <webwork:property value="./genericValue">
            <webwork:property value="./long('id')">
                <webwork:if
test="/customFieldHidden(/issue/long('project'), .) == false">
                    <customfield>
                        <customfieldname><webwork:property
value="../string('name')" /></customfieldname>
                        <customfieldvalue><webwork:if
test="/customFieldValue(..) != null"><webwork:property
value="/customFieldValue(..)" escape="true"
/></webwork:if></customfieldvalue>
                    </customfield>
                </webwork:if>
            </webwork:property>
            </webwork:property>
        </webwork:iterator>
        </customfields>
<comments>
<%
String queryString = request.getQueryString();
int startIndex = queryString.indexOf("key=") + 4;
int endIndex = queryString.indexOf("&",startIndex);
if (endIndex == -1) { endIndex = queryString.length(); }
String key = queryString.substring(startIndex, endIndex);
                                                                                                                                                             
List comments =
ManagerFactory.getIssueManager().getEntitiesByIssue(com.atlassian.jira.i
ssue.IssueRelationConstants.COMMENTS,
ManagerFactory.getIssueManager().getIssue(key));
                                                                                                                                                             
for (Iterator iterator = comments.iterator(); iterator.hasNext(); ) {
     GenericValue comment = (GenericValue) iterator.next();
     out.print("<comment><![CDATA[");
     out.print(comment.get("body"));
     out.println("]]></comment>");
                                                                                                                                                             
}
%>
</comments>
</item>


I personally think that we should put the comments bit into issuedetails-rss.jsp.
fields.summary: Include comments in XML format of an issue

fields.description:
A custom select field should always have a "No value" option. Current behaviour hides this option when a field is set as required, thus a valid value will automatically selected. Desired behaviour would force the user into a choice.

(Note this description was updated on 7/Dec/2004)
fields.summary: Select list custom fields has no "none" value when required

fields.description:
The 'attachment' field is wiped during issue creation if any of the input fields require corrections after validation.

The field should retain the string entered.
fields.summary: Attachment field is wiped during issue creation if input fields require corrections.

fields.description:
Moving 'Attachment' to be an actual issue field provides users with greate control over the field in issue creation - e.g. adding a further description, hiding the field and re-ordering the field.

However, 'Attachment' should be hideable but not requireable and not required - always optional.

When editing an issue, if 'Attachment' was set as required, this would mean that an attachment would need to be added each time.

This does not fit with the current issue field design - which enforces a field to be either requireable or required.
fields.summary: Migrate 'Attachment' to be an issue field

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-3663].
  {panel}

Issue fields requires some re-design for greater flexibility.

For example, in migrating the field 'Attachment' to be an actual issue field, there are a number of areas that prove problematic and restrictive.

(The migration of the 'Attachment' field to an actual issue field allows greater user control as with all issue fields - e.g. in this case, the field can be hidden, further description added and it can be reordered.)

The 'Attachment' field is unique in that we wish it be 'hideable', not 'requireable' and not required by default - i.e. it can never be set to be required - it is always optional.

At present, the current design enforces that an issue field is either required by default or requirable.

Checks if a field is 'requirable' are used throughout - and this determines the fields requirability - both in the UI and the system code.

Further, a second check is made against a collection of 'required' fields that all 'requireable' fields are added to - this check appears to be redundant.

The hierarchy of fields could also be re-designed. With the introduction of a field that is hideable, not required and not requireable - it would seem beneficial to separate the HideableField interface from the RequireableField interface. This could lead to the introduction of the NavigableHideableFieldImpl and NavigableHideableRequireableFieldImpl classes.
fields.summary: Issue Fields requires some re-design for greater flexibility

fields.description:
if time entry is enabled, the user should be prompted to enter time for the issue before resolving it. if an issue is resolved, the time remaining should be set to zero, right?

similarly, when reopening an issue, one should be prompted to re-estimate the amount of time remaining.
fields.summary: prompt for time entry on 'resolve issue'
Deleting a Global field

fields.description:
Some users have accounts with umlaut characters (ä, ö, ü etc.) in their login name. When clicking on the user in the user list of the admin dialog an error message is displayed "The user M ller does not exist". It is now impossible to modify their entries.

Although special characters are no longer allowed in JIRA 2.6.1, we have existing users which still have login names with umlauts, who created their accounts with earlier JIRA releases.
fields.summary: user names with umlauts can't be modified
Create a print style sheet using media="print" so users don't need print button

fields.description:
Just tried installing JIRA 2.6.1 Enterprise -- installed ok, but after creating a project, creating a bug in that project, and finally trying to add that project to my dashboard -- it seems to have melted down. :-(

Now I cannot even log into JIRA.

Upon startup, I found this trace in the tomcat stdout.log which I realize uses "POSITION" as a fieldname -- something which is VERBOTEN in HSQLDB 1.7.2RC5 and above. POSITION is a reserved token in SQL apparently. FYI -- it can still be used if the field is fully qualified with the tablename, ex.PORTLETCONFIGURATION.POSITION, but it would be better to change the fieldname.

I use the name "ORDINAL" -- Check webster.com for the def'n:

"1 : a number designating the place (as first, second, or third) occupied by an item in an ordered sequence"

In the meantime -- is there a way I can workaround this?

Cheers,
Timo
